title: Quiz 3: Control & Communication
description: A detailed assessment of the body's control systems: The Nervous System (Ch 7), Special Senses (Ch 8), and The Endocrine System (Ch 9). Covers neural transmission, brain function, sensory perception, and hormonal regulation.

questions.question: Which ion is primarily responsible for the rapid depolarization phase of a neuronal action potential?
questions.explanation: When a neuron is stimulated, sodium channels open and Na+ floods into the cell, reversing the resting potential (depolarization). Potassium outflow is responsible for repolarization.
questions.hint: This ion rushes INTO the cell to make it positive.

questions.question: Match the brain region with its primary function:

pairs.right: Higher mental functions, memory, voluntary movement
Coordination, balance, and fine motor control

questions.explanation: Cerebrum=Thinking/Consciousness. Cerebellum=Balance/Coordination. Medulla=Vital Signs. Hypothalamus=Homeostasis/Master Controller.
questions.hint: Think 'Bellum' = Balance; 'Thalamus' = Temperature.

questions.question: Which of the following are physiological effects of SYMPATHETIC nervous system stimulation ('Fight or Flight')? (Select all that apply)

richContent.content: Scenario: You are walking alone at night and suddenly hear a loud crash behind you. Your body instantly reacts.

options.text: Constriction of blood vessels to the skin and digestive tract

questions.explanation: The sympathetic system prepares the body for action: increasing visual field (pupils), oxygen intake (bronchioles), and directing blood to muscles/heart/brain (constricting skin/gut vessels). Digestion is inhibited.
questions.hint: What helps you run away from danger?

questions.question: The gap between two neurons where chemical transmission of an impulse occurs is called the ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: The synapse (or synaptic cleft) is the junction where neurotransmitters are released to signal the next neuron.
questions.hint: Starts with 'S'.

questions.question: Arrange the components of a simple REFLEX ARC in the order an impulse travels.
questions.explanation: Stimulus -> Receptor -> Afferent path -> CNS -> Efferent path -> Effector -> Response.
questions.hint: Input comes before Processing, which comes before Output.

questions.question: Which endocrine gland is located in the neck, butterfly-shaped, and regulates metabolic rate?
questions.explanation: The thyroid gland wraps around the trachea and secretes T3 and T4, which control basal metabolic rate.
questions.hint: It's near the 'Adam's Apple'.

questions.question: What is the name of the white, fatty substance that insulates axons and increases the speed of nerve impulse transmission?
questions.explanation: Myelin allows for saltatory conduction, greatly increasing speed.
questions.hint: Starts with 'M'. Damage to this causes Multiple Sclerosis.

questions.question: Match the hormone with the gland that produces it:
questions.explanation: Insulin=Pancreas. Cortisol=Adrenal Cortex. GH=Pituitary. Adrenaline=Adrenal Medulla.
questions.hint: Sugar regulation vs Stress regulation.

questions.question: The Posterior Pituitary gland synthesizes its own hormones (ADH and Oxytocin).
questions.explanation: FALSE. The posterior pituitary STORES and RELEASES ADH and Oxytocin, but they are SYNTHESIZED in the Hypothalamus and travel down axons to the posterior pituitary.
questions.hint: Does it make them or just store them?

questions.question: Identify the refractive structure of the eye described below.

richContent.content: A biconvex, transparent, flexible structure located behind the pupil. It changes shape (accommodation) to focus light rays onto the retina for near or far vision.

questions.explanation: The lens is the only structure that can change shape (via ciliary muscles) to adjust focus. The cornea refracts light but is fixed.
questions.hint: Like the glass part of a camera or glasses.

questions.question: Order the pathway of sound waves through the ear until they generate a nerve impulse.

items.text: Cochlear fluid / Hair cells in Spiral Organ

questions.explanation: Sound enters the outer ear -> vibrates eardrum -> moves bones -> pushes oval window -> creates fluid waves in cochlea stimulating hair cells.
questions.hint: Air -> Membrane -> Bone -> Fluid.

questions.question: Which of the following are differences between RODS and CONES in the retina? (Select all that apply)

richContent.content:
FeatureDescription
Light SensitivityOne works in dim light, one requires bright light
ColorOne is monochromatic, one sees color

options.text: Rods are for dim light/night vision; Cones are for bright light
Cones provide color vision; Rods provide black & white vision
Rods are most concentrated in the fovea centralis
Cones are more numerous than rods
Vitamin A is required for the synthesis of rhodopsin in Rods

questions.explanation: Rods = Dim light, B&W, peripheral retina. Cones = Bright light, Color, concentrated in fovea centralis. Rods far outnumber cones.
questions.hint: C for Cones, C for Color.

questions.question: The hormone ___BLANK___ lowers blood glucose levels, while the hormone ___BLANK___ raises blood glucose levels.
questions.explanation: Insulin lowers glucose (storage). Glucagon raises glucose (release). Both are from the pancreas.
questions.hint: One is injected by diabetics; the other sounds like 'glucose gone'.

questions.question: Match the visual disorder with its description:

pairs.right: Nearsightedness (image focuses in front of retina)
Loss of lens elasticity due to aging (difficulty reading)

questions.explanation: Myopia = Near. Hyperopia = Far. Presbyopia = Old eyes. Cataract = Cloudy.
questions.hint: 'Presby' means old/elder.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a NEGATIVE feedback loop involving the thyroid gland?

options.text: Low T3/T4 -> Hypothalamus releases TRH -> Pituitary releases TSH -> Thyroid releases T3/T4
High T3/T4 -> Hypothalamus releases more TRH -> Thyroid releases more T3/T4
Low T3/T4 -> Pituitary releases ACTH -> Adrenal gland responds

questions.explanation: In negative feedback, low levels stimulate production. Low T3/T4 triggers TRH -> TSH -> more T3/T4. Once levels rise, they inhibit TRH/TSH production.
questions.hint: The body tries to fix the deficit (Low levels -> Stimulate production).

questions.question: What is the name of the fluid that circulates in the subarachnoid space and ventricles, providing protection and buoyancy to the CNS?
questions.explanation: Cerebrospinal Fluid (CSF) cushions the brain and spinal cord.
questions.hint: Three letter acronym starts with 'C'.

questions.question: Which cranial nerve is responsible for the sense of smell?
questions.explanation: Cranial Nerve I is the Olfactory nerve (Smell). Optic is II.
questions.hint: It is the very first cranial nerve.

questions.question: Select the structures found in the MIDDLE ear. (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The Middle Ear contains the ossicles (Malleus, Incus, Stapes) and the opening of the Eustachian tube. The Cochlea and Semicircular canals are Inner Ear.
questions.hint: Think 'bones' and 'tubes', not 'snails' or 'loops'.

questions.question: Which pathology is caused by the hypersecretion of Growth Hormone (GH) in adulthood (after epiphyseal plates have closed)?
questions.explanation: Hypersecretion of GH in adulthood causes Acromegaly (thickening of bones/tissues). In childhood (before plates close), it causes Gigantism (lengthening of bones).
questions.hint: Look for the term associated with adults.

questions.question: Order the layers of the meninges from OUTERMOST (skull) to INNERMOST (brain surface).
questions.explanation: Outer=Dura (Tough). Middle=Arachnoid (Spider-web). Inner=Pia (Delicate/adhered to brain).
questions.hint: D-A-P.

questions.question: Match the adrenal hormone with its category/function:
questions.explanation: Aldosterone=Minerals(Salt). Cortisol=Glucose/Stress. Androgens=Sex. Adrenaline=Fight/Flight.
questions.hint: Mineral- for minerals, Gluco- for sugar/energy.

questions.question: The blood-brain barrier protects the brain by preventing the passage of all substances from the blood into brain tissue.
questions.explanation: FALSE. It is SELECTIVE. It allows essential substances like glucose and oxygen to pass, but blocks toxins, wastes, and many drugs.
questions.hint: If it blocked everything, how would the brain get fed?

questions.question: Which part of the ear is responsible for static equilibrium (gravity/linear acceleration) and dynamic equilibrium (rotational movement)?

richContent.content:
Structures:
1. Semicircular Canals
2. Vestibule (Utricle & Saccule)

questions.explanation: The Vestibular Apparatus (Semicircular canals + Vestibule) controls balance. The Cochlea controls hearing.
questions.hint: It shares the nerve name 'Vestibulo-...'.

questions.question: Name the condition characterized by increased intraocular pressure that can lead to blindness if untreated.
questions.explanation: Glaucoma is caused by poor drainage of aqueous humor, raising pressure and damaging the optic nerve.
questions.hint: Starts with 'G'.

questions.question: Which of the following symptoms are associated with Hypothyroidism (Myxoedema)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Hypothyroidism slows metabolism: Weight gain, Cold, Slow heart, Sluggishness. Hyperthyroidism speeds it up (Weight loss, Heat, Fast heart).
questions.hint: Think 'Slow' and 'Cold'.

questions.question: The ___BLANK___ area in the frontal lobe is responsible for the production of speech, while ___BLANK___ area in the temporal lobe is responsible for understanding speech.
questions.explanation: Broca's area = Motor speech (Production). Wernicke's area = Sensory speech (Comprehension).
questions.hint: Broca is Broken speech (production issue).

questions.question: Which cells in the pancreatic islets secrete Glucagon?
questions.explanation: Alpha cells secrete Glucagon. Beta cells secrete Insulin. Delta cells secrete Somatostatin.
questions.hint: A comes before B; G comes before I (alphabetically, usually inverted logic, but here Alpha=Glucagon).

questions.question: Match the Cranial Nerve number with its name:
questions.explanation: I=Smell. II=Sight. V=Face Sensation/Chewing. X=Vagus (Wanderer to viscera).
questions.hint: X is 10.

questions.question: The 'blind spot' (optic disc) contains the highest concentration of cones for sharp vision.
questions.explanation: FALSE. The blind spot (optic disc) has NO photoreceptors (rods or cones) because it is where the optic nerve exits. The Fovea Centralis has the highest concentration of cones.
questions.hint: It is called 'blind' for a reason.

questions.question: Trace the path of light through the eye to the retina.
questions.explanation: Light passes through: Cornea -> Aqueous -> Pupil -> Lens -> Vitreous -> Retina.
questions.hint: Front surface to back surface.
